title: 112_s1906
content:
The "Cabin Fee Act of 2011" includes sections on short title, definitions, cabin user fees, cabin transfer fees, right of appeal and judicial review, consistency with other law and rights, and regulations. The "Cabin Fee Act of 2011" defines terms such as authorization, cabin, and cabin owner for the Recreation Residence Program on National Forest System land. The "Cabin Fee Act of 2011" defines terms related to cabin fees, including cabin transfer fee, cabin user fee, and current appraisal cycle. The "Cabin Fee Act of 2011" defines terms such as lot, National Forest System land, Recreation Residence Program, and Secretary. The "Cabin Fee Act of 2011" defines a typical lot as a cabin lot or group of cabin lots in a tract selected for appraisal, representing similar value characteristics as other lots within the tract. The "Cabin Fee Act of 2011" defines a typical lot as a cabin lot or group of cabin lots in a tract selected for appraisal, representing similar value characteristics as other lots within the tract. SEC. 3. CABIN USER FEES. The Secretary establishes annual cabin user fees for cabin owners on National Forest System land. Initial cabin user fees are assigned to value tiers based on appraised lot values adjusted for price changes. The Forest Service establishes fee tiers for cabin owners based on adjusted appraised lot values. Second appraisals that are not rejected supersede initial values. Tiers range from 1 to 9 based on lot value, with percentages outlined in a table. Incomplete appraisals cannot be used for tier establishment. The Secretary will assess an interim fee for cabin lots until assigned to a fee tier, which is the lesser of $4,500 or 25% more than the current cabin user fee. Initial cabin user fees are based on assignments and tier values. Tier 1: 8% of permits, $500 fee
Tier 2: 12% of permits, $1,000 fee
Tier 3: 12% of permits, $1,500 fee
Tier 4: 14% of permits, $2,000 fee
Tier 5: 14% of permits, $2,500 fee Tier 6: 14% permits, $3,000
Tier 7: 11% permits, $3,500
Tier 8: 8% permits, $4,000
Tier 9: 7% permits, $4,500. The Secretary must complete the current appraisal cycle within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Cabin user fees will start in the first calendar year after the cycle. Annual adjustments to fees will be based on changes in the Implicit Price Deflator for GDP on a 5-year average. Fees can only be increased within limitations. Fees established under this section can be increased by up to 25 percent annually. The Secretary can reduce the cabin user fee to $100 per year if the cabin is destroyed, substantially damaged, or access is significantly impaired. The cabin user fee can be reduced to $100 per year if the cabin is destroyed, substantially damaged, or access is significantly impaired. The fee reduction is effective until the last day of the year of the incident or until normal access is restored. SEC. 4. CABIN TRANSFER FEES. Cabin owners transferring ownership must declare the amount received and pay a transfer fee to the Secretary for a new permit. Transfer fees for cabin ownership transfers are based on the consideration received. The fee is $1,000 for amounts up to $250,000, $1,000 plus 5% of the excess for amounts between $250,000.01 to $500,000, and $1,000 plus 5% of the excess for amounts above $500,000. Transfer fees for cabin ownership transfers are based on the consideration received, ranging from $1,000 up to $500,000 plus 10 percent of the excess amount over $500,000. The Secretary will use changes in the Implicit Price Deflator for the Gross Domestic Product to adjust the cabin transfer fee threshold amounts annually. The Secretary grants cabin owners the right to appeal new cabin fees and transfers. Appeals follow specific regulations. Cabin owners can contest final decisions in court. Venue for actions under this subsection is in the Federal judicial district where the cabin is located or the permit holder resides. Seeking mediation for actions under this Act is not precluded. SEC. 6. EFFECT. This Act does not limit the United States' rights to any land or resource. In Alaska, cabin user fees must comply with the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. SEC. 7. REGULATIONS. The Secretary must issue regulations by December 31, 2012, to implement this Act.
